comments.commentBody:
That was a proper Saturday work out. My first time through all the clues I had two answers, 2D: ALEPHS, and 22A: PRU, for the Prudential building (on the right in the photo above). 15 A, I knew had to end in OVA, because all Russian ballerinas' names end in OVA, da? And slowly it fell. How I knew that SPICA was the brightest star in Virgo is beyond me. That was pulled from outer space.

I really like the fact that there was a kind of theme; really, a set of less-than-helpful clues. The SW corner was the last to fall for me , and it CAMEAT me in a true ADAGIO.

At the time it seemed as if I needed to do it, but now I regret having googled the Faulkner story. My one cheat, and I didn't help. Should have waited but I wanted that (38A) (37A).
Completely unfair.  Sure there lots of Gimmes (e.g. ULANOVA, HAEC, ENZO), but the "triumphant shout"s -- ugh.  For those of us who have never triumphed, these were just impossible. DNT!

None of this really matters.  Jeffers et. al. took one quote from a youtube video and ranted and raved about it for almost the entire length of Sotomayor's hearings.  Whether there's a long paper trail or a short one, the only thing that counts is whether there's any quote of any kind that may be twisted sufficiently to make a catchy Fox-News soundbite.  I'm sure they'll find something; and after that, those of us who watch will have to endure an endless repetition of prosecutorial questions hoping to box any future Obama nominees into a tighter, conservative-friendly "judicial philosophy."  She'll probably do fine just to say her job is to "call balls and strikes," huh, Mr. Roberts? (He hates it when you call him "Mister.")
Good luck with that, maybe they can make the CBO scores and the Dartmouth study the centerpiece of their campaign!

You folks out of power frustrated? Well, good and get used to it. The Party of No is more than saying no to necessary reforms. The Party of No has no ideas, no vision, no ideals, no direction, (very important) no leaders, no help and ,especially, no hope. Please keep up the mindless, predictable blather and see in November how many concerned, thoughtful voters you attract. Can't wait to see your pain come November 3, 2010.

This article has so far attracted the same canned, unthinking comments by the same unthinking kneejerk opponents of anything done by government that might help anything or anyone - other than themselves.  Hey, it's called a community of interests, stupids, and it (unlike Ayn Rand and free market theocracy) is truly rational and basic to humanity.

Ed in Hoboken: Do you always wear a seat belt when you're riding in the back? Do you every jaywalk? Do you ever eat cheeseburgers or eat sugary foods? Do you go to your doctor annually, and follow his/her advice? I exercise almost daily, eat 7-8 servings of fruits and vegetables daily, don't smoke and don't drink. But I've come to appreciate that almost nobody is perfect in how they approach health matters. And like a lot of other people, I wish the bill went further (with a public health option), but I don't like what it says about us as a nation that we'vebeen willing to let up to 45,000 people die every year for lack of insurance. How does that make us a great nation?

The objections to this bill are just about all of the same stripe. If it were automobile insurance they would be saying "I am a careful driver. I never do bad things. Why should I have to pay for the carelessness of others". Yet each of them would want to be able to run to their brokers the moment they had a major accident to demand coverage. How idiotic to think that if you run a mile or two, eat your veggies and take your supplements you will be safe from cancer, cardiovascular disease, neurodegenerative diseases and various dementias. These are the same individuals, who, when they are struck by a serious illness, will seek someone to blame or some "environmental poison"  or some corporation or government entity for sabotaging their supposedly perfect and perfectly cared for bodies.

Good news -- we need to fight back the lies and negativity. This law is long overdue and will get better and more entrenched in our lives over time...for the better. For those haters who keep slamming this bill...truth and morality will triumph over lies and misinformation. You lost this round and you'll lose in the long run.

#32 - jacobi

You're absolutely right. Obama's slowness in okaying those berms reminds me of his painfully slow response to recent Islamic terrorist attacks at Fort Hood and the Christmas Day airplane bomb plot. In all of these cases, Obama has allowed his liberal ideology to prevent him and his administration from taking obvious actions that seem like no-brainer decisions to the rest of us. It's scary that this oil spill is demonstrating that we have a President who is so competely out-of-touch with reality.

I keep hearing people blame Obama for the spill. I'm confused as to what they think he should do? Swim down himself and plug the hole with superhuman powers? Snap his fingers and make all the oil go away? Engineer a fail-proof containment pod himself?

If you were in his position, what would you do? How would you seal the leak?

I just want to point out, for the record, that it was the Obama Administration's management of the U.S. Minerals Management Service which waived the preparation of an Environmental Impact Statement for this well. It was the Obama Administration which did not require a full blown casualty response plan.

I also want to point out that the Times now has a dead dolphin photo, one of 4 now floating around on the internet.

I wonder if Sasha and Malia know that "Daddy killed Flipper"?

Progressive Democrats need to start working, now, to find an experienced adult, not beholden to Wall Street, to run against President Obama in the 2012 primaries.

These pictures are very sad. What is also really sad is that most folks do not see the connection between the cruel death of these animals, and the cruel death of the animals we eat. If you feel powerless, as many here have stated, then empower yourselves by seeing the bird in your chicken mc nugget, by seeing the calf in your veal. All animals feel pain & fear, not just the ones in the wild. Love the animal kingdom by not eating them.
Depressing to see these creatures suffer due to another human interference with nature gone awry. When will we learn?
Ashamed to be of the human species.
What an excellent piece.
Funny how these people destroy lives and then, with the money in their pockets, "strive to make a better World"...
Thank heavens Matthews is gone.  Addition by subtraction, regardless of how well Tejada does.

"The worst you can do for the ones you love the most, is what they could and should do for themselves."
RIP, mr, wooden.
Rest in peace. You are a legend in our time. Thank you.

This is only a story, not a lesson: I saw John Wooden once, a few years ago. He was living in the same building in Encino as a relative with whom I was staying, and I saw him dash into his car and drive away hurriedly as I was walking to mine. At the time, I had the notion of leaving a basketball and a marker with my relative, hoping he would sign it some day. My relative shooed the idea away, but I always wondered if he would have signed it indeed. At least I am glad for the glimpse I got.

May he always be remembered in the game of basketball.

A 100% class act and gentleman, here is Coach Wooden's 7 point creed.

• Be true to yourself.
• Make each day your masterpiece.
• Help others.
• Drink deeply from good books, especially the Bible.
• Make friendship a fine art.
• Build a shelter against a rainy day.
• Pray for guidance and give thanks for your blessings every day.

What a great coach, & a great man. One thing this obit does not mention, but I had read a few months ago, was that Mr. Wooden actually scored not only a hole in one, but also the far more rare double eagle (a deuce on a par 5) in  THE SAME 18 HOLE ROUND!!! This was while he was still living in the Midwest, & fairly young. Suffice it to say, I doubt very few people have ever accomplished that feat.

I had the distinct pleasure of being a student at UCLA for Coach Wooden's last 4 years as coach there. That was in the middle of his 88 game winning streak, a feat highly unlikely to be duplicated or surpassed. Coach Wooden lived his life on his own terms and set an incredible example for all of us. I am saddened by his passing yet celebrate the incredible 99 years that the world was fortunate to have this wonderful human being for. Rest in peace coach and go be with Nell.
A great and good human being has left us. May his examples and lessons remain.
